recordings.rmk: Ends of recording trimmed; normalised to -3db; otherwise unedited.

Calls from a perched Goldfinch that flies off. As the bird flies away, the call notes fade.  The 'signature' call, delivered twice at the start of the clip (and again just after 0:08), is a regular component of the repertoire both at rest and in flight.
Subsong

recordings.rmk: a big group, more than 40, C.c. in trees between farm and field, flying away, landing, sitting and singing, together with some Greenfinches. Nearby there is a field with sunflowers which has not been harvested last year, and in there a lot of birds, particulary  Corvus frugileus and about 400 C.c. mostly are sitting.

a big group 0f C.C. (about 80) in trees between farm and field, flying away, landing, sitting and singing, together with some Greenfinches. Nearby there is a field with sunflowers which has not been harvested last year, and in there a lot of birds, particulary  Corvus frugileus and about 400 C.c. mostly are sitting.

recordings.file-name: XC332073-Goldfinch song and juv calls 15 July 2016 0640.mp3
recordings.rmk: An adult Goldfinch singing (almost invisibly) from within the canopy of a 3m tall Sycamore tree. An unknown number of others were within earshot, some of which were juveniles. Nesting had occurred nearby and the birds were probably from the same family group.  Richness in Goldfinch song is based upon fairly similar phrases that are either shortened or lengthened or have the ending 'tweaked'. At times I hear a resemblance to the terminal flourish that often characteristic of Chaffinch song. This bird was uttering random short and clipped call notes that seem to be the standard flight call but are also woven into the song's delivery, albeit isolated within song phrases. Examples can be heard at 0:04, 0:07 and 0:19 Goldfinches make a scolding 'hissy rattle' in situations of aggression, such as defending a feeder port or asserting rites. A fleeting example of the sound can be heard at 0:40. From 0:50 to the end, the lilting tittering of juveniles can be heard. Other calls from, I assume, the same birds are at XC332135.

recordings.loc: Serranía de Ronda (near  Ronda), Málaga, Andalucía

recordings.rmk: Flock
In flight
A few birds on thistles

When coming along a small way, a young European Goldfinch which seemed just had left its nest, fluttered towards me, climbed up my trousers and then fluttered from my bycicle to a hedge and the top of an apple tree. There it called and called. (►XC266536). Lateron in the evening the same situation, but now it called more powerfull (►XC266541). When we hided, we were glad to see adult Goldfinches contacting it.

**Behaviour**: Bird obstructed by canopy. Singing from atop a tree.

**Sex (with ID cues)**: N/A

**Weather and other conditions**: Clear evening, little windy.

**Comments on other birds**: Alarming Blackbird (*Turdus merula*) can be heard in the background.

recordings.rmk: Rural garden. EQ adjusted below 2000 Hz to reduce road noise. Identification based on other recordings such as XC433048 by david m where two different calls can be heard best from 2m41s. I cannot rule out there being siskins hiding in the background too. Lesser redpolls also live in this garden but I do not think they feature in this recording.

recordings.file-name: XC377873-carduelis carduelis (esperanza poveda) linares de la sierra 04-05-2017.mp3
recordings.rmk: El hábitat es un bosque serrano de tipo atlántico, algo poco frecuente en estas latitudes, con roble melojo, quejigo y plantaciones de castaño. El sotobosque está compuesto de helechos y toda una rica comunidad de matorral mediterráneo.

El hábitat es bosque serrano de clima suave, algo poco común en estas latitudes, con roble melojo y quejigo además de plantaciones de castaño. El sotobosque es de helechos además de toda una rica comunidad de matorral mediterráneo.
